awd_titl_txt: Next Generation Data Analysis For Next Generation Cosmic Microwave Background Experiments.
awd_abstract_narration:
The Big Bang explosion at the beginning of the Universe left behind a glow of radiation in microwaves.  Scientists using the next generation of microwave telescopes will study this radiation for signatures of primordial gravitational waves that are theorized but as yet unseen.  These waves were created by quantum fluctuations during the Universe's first moments, and finding them would push the frontiers of physics.  This project will develop mathematical, statistical, and computational tools to better map and analyze the data from these telescope measurements.  It helps sponsor the research and training of the next generation of scientists at the undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral level.  To ensure that exciting developments in early Universe research reach the broader community, this project focuses on attracting new students to STEM disciplines with public talks and school visits, college-level curriculum development, and high-quality STEM student mentoring.

This project will advance the state of the art for Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) analysis tools, with a focus on understanding and developing the role of the new "messenger method" approach to map-making and filtering.  It will develop messenger map-making into a production-ready tool and apply it to data.  Ground-based CMB observatories produce maps with complex, anisotropic noise correlations.  Messenger methods can account for wider varieties of such correlations and serve as the basis for new power spectrum estimation tools.  Additionally, messenger methods may allow for multiple tracers of the large-scale matter field to be combined with CMB lensing into a single tomographic matter atlas.  The well-characterized synthesis of a mass map from multiple tracers is important for the epoch of wide field cosmology surveys.  This project will promote the existing "Saturday Morning Physics" outreach lecture series at Florida State University and other K-12 activities.  Furthermore, training of students, including undergraduates, helps to prepare the next generation of STEM workers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For mapmaking, we showed that the "cooling scheme" suggested by the messenger method is particularly effective when there is significant low-frequency noise in the timestream data. More traditional (conjugate gradient) algorithms applied to this modified system converge faster and to a higher fidelity solution, and give the best overall approach.

We examined the prospects to generate CMB map noise realizations using sampling approaches. In principle, this could allow for more efficient and complete characterization of the covariance of statistics derived from the CMB maps.  We found that we can generate samples of noise realizations (via a Gibbs sampling method), and that this method works well at small scales, but at the largest scales, the noise samples have long correlation lengths. That is, it takes many samples to generate independent realizations. Thus the method may not be more efficient than the previous technique of conducting map making on independent noise realizations (as, for example, the Planck mission did with its full-focal-plane simulations). Many variations on the sampling algorithm we tried were not able to address sufficiently this correlation-length issue. Thus, barring any future advance, it unfortunately does not now appear that messenger-based methods are a magic bullet to characterize the uncertainties in CMB mapmaking.

Separately, for map filtering, we adapted a multi-stage messenger method filtering code to use the pixelization and software framework developed for the Simons Observatory. 

We also made several studies of large scale structure.  We presented cosmological constraints derived from the Subaru Hyper Suprime-Cam first-year weak lensing shear maps.  These were unique in using non-Gaussian statistics: counts of peaks and minima.  We show that these statistics contain significant cosmological information and are complementary to traditional 2-point statistics (power spectra).  We designed a system of emulators that use forward-modeled N-body simulations to characterize the statistics for parameter inference with Markov Chain Monte Carlo sampling. By combining peaks, minima, and the power spectrum, and assuming a flat-ΛCDM cosmological model, we obtained tighter constraints on the matter fluctuations in the Universe.

Other work cross-correlated Atacama Cosmology Telescope CMB lensing with Dark Energy Survey galaxies at six epochs over cosmic time.  This allows us to place constraints again on matter clustering and on the time evolution of the structure.  We publicly released a code to generate mock galaxy and CMB lensing maps that are distributed like lognormal random fields.

In an unexpected turn, we worked on searches for mm-wave transient objects, like stellar flares, developing several new techniques.

The project supported K-12 education through "Saturday Morning Physics" programs at Florida State University.  The PI and a supported postdoc presented in the "CMB-S4 Saturday Space Science Series," organized by a supported graduate student.  The PI presented to Florida State University's Young Scholar's Program for talented high-school students.

The project also provided many training and mentorship opportunities.  It supported the work of two postdocs, two graduate students, three undergraduates, and one high-school intern.  Over the course of the award, the PI worked as a mentor to four different postdocs at outside institutions in the Simons Observatory mentorship program.
